title: Sky TV reports downturn on eve of merger ruling
text:
Sky TV reports downturn on eve of merger ruling TOM PULLAR-STRECKER Last updated 09:11, February 22 2017 SUPPLIED 
Sky chief executive John Fellet will find out on Thursday if the company's merger with Vodafone NZ is likely to proceed. 
Sky Television has reported a drop in viewers as it waits to find out whether the country's competition watchdog will approve its planned merger with Vodafone NZ. 
The company said total subscriber numbers fell from 852,679 to 816,135 in the six months to December 31. Its net profit fell 32 per cent to $59 million and revenues were down 3.7 per cent at $458m. 
The result was released under the shadow of a ruling from the Commerce Commission, which will announce on Thursday whether it will allow Sky TV to merge its business with Vodafone NZ. DAVID WHITE/FAIRFAX NZ 
Spark boss Simon Moutter says he has dropped Sky's broadcaster service fully this time. 
A commission spokesman said it would not release the reasoning for its pending decision until a later date. 
READ MORE: 
Spark managing director Simon Moutter had a dig at Sky on the eve of the results, tweeting that he had ditched Sky's broadcast service, and this time that appears to be a clean cut. 
Spark launched a rival internet service, Lightbox, in 2014 and is opposing Sky's proposed merger with Vodafone. Cut the cord on my last Sky TV box, it's sitting on my desk while I think of what to do with it... watch this space! pic.twitter.com/iI19YkvrS8 — Simon Moutter (@simonmoutter) February 21, 2017 
Moutter had tweeted in September that he had sent his Sky box back to Sky, not mentioning that he had kept one decoder, which he used to watch Sky Sports. Sending my box back to Sky TV. So much better value with Lightbox and other on demand streaming services nowadays. pic.twitter.com/TlYleHeTmD Ad Feedback 
Most Sky Sports programming can be viewed without a decoder through Sky's standalone FanPass online service. 
Spark and 2degrees are set to find out on Wednesday whether the High Court in Auckland will grant them a legal stay which would prevent Sky TV and Vodafone NZ enacting their merger until 36 hours after the commission releases the detailed reasoning for its decision – in the event it gave approval for the merger. 
The companies say they might need the delay so they could seek a judicial review before the possible merger became a fait accompli. - Stuff
